data.title: Charlie Gladstone may be descended from the late great prime minister and live in a castle, but he and his wife have prospered by following a more down-to-earth path
data.meta_description: He may be heir to two country estates and great-great grandson of the revered Liberal prime minister, but Charlie Gladstone has had to make his own way in life.
data.text:
He may be heir to two country estates and great-great grandson of the revered Liberal PM, but Charlie Gladstone has had to make his own way in life. Here, for the first time, he shares his family’s story and explains how he created a quirky business empire alongside his wife Caroline

Just because he's the heir to two large country estates, both boasting impressive castles – the legacy of being the great-great grandson of 19th-century Liberal prime minister William Ewart Gladstone – doesn’t mean that Charlie Gladstone doesn’t know how to get his hands dirty. Such as deep down in the mud on his organic farm in Wales or getting dusty and covered in cobwebs while scouring tucked-away brocantes in France in search of interesting vintage finds.

Yet it’s a story Charlie, and his wife Caroline, best known for starting the online retailer Pedlars and now the proud co-founders of The Good Life Experience – a food, music and craft festival held on their estate in Flintshire – have previously chosen to leave untold.

Maybe that’s simply because of the kind of down-to-earth, understated people that they are or maybe it’s not wanting to appear smug in boasting of such an illustrious heritage.

But for the first time, they’ve agreed to share their family’s story exclusively with YOU.

Charlie’s is not a typical inheritance tale.

Yes, there are the magnificent estates – the 16th-century Balbegno Castle in Kincardineshire, Scotland (renovated and rented out as a self-catering holiday home), and nearby, the Gladstones’ 15-bedroom, 200-year-old hunting lodge family home in Glen Dye, in the foothills of the Grampians, where the operational site for Pedlars is based.

Then there’s Hawarden Estate in North Wales, with ‘new’ Hawarden Castle, William Gladstone’s former home with his wife Catherine Glynne, and the location for the UK’s only residential and prime ministerial library, housing Gladstone’s collection of 32,000 books (as part of a greater collection of 250,000 books, journals, pamphlets and personal papers).

It is where Eton-educated Charlie grew up and where his parents are still based (the ruins of the original Norman Hawarden Castle are in the estate’s grounds).

So far, so privileged – but you soon begin to realise that Charlie and Caroline, who have six children, prove an exception to the rule.

Charlie is like a bouncing puppy, with endless energy and a nose for sniffing out adventures and treasures; Caroline is cool, calm and measured with a deep, endearing laugh.

Together for almost 30 years, they’ve worked exceptionally hard to bring their entrepreneurial flair to all manner of ventures – not least Pedlars, established in 1997 and now a vast emporium of tantalising British-made homewares and vintage finds (with an eponymous general store and café in West London’s Notting Hill), but also The Magnificent Hound, an online source of accessories for dogs and their owners launched last year, along with the renovation of The Glynne Arms pub near to their award-winning Hawarden Estate farm shop in Wales, and, since last year, festival promoters.

The couple are straightforward and likable.

‘We simply try to be honest. We are who we are and we do what we do,’ says Charlie.

Preaching is a no-no, says Caroline.

‘When we published Pedlars’ Guide to the Great Outdoors three years ago,’ she says of their how-to guide for camping, fishing, rambling and wild food foraging, ‘we just wanted to share our passion and experience.’

‘We also appreciate that we don’t need to be doing all these things to survive,’ says Charlie.

‘We could be much more financially successful if we decided to stick to one business venture.’

It all started when Caroline and Charlie met at a New Year’s Eve party after leaving university. Charlie had studied at Oxford and Caroline, a diplomat’s daughter, went to Cambridge. They were married aged 24.

Charlie fell into music A&R, discovering The Charlatans and managing They Might Be Giants for Warner Music, while Caroline worked as a designer at Laura Ashley, until Charlie inherited the family’s estate in the Scottish Highlands.

Moving to Scotland, with their eldest child Jack as a young baby, was an opportunity not to be missed, even if no one else thought it made any sense.

‘We both gave up our jobs and moved on a whim, with just a few months’ notice,’ says Charlie.

‘Everyone thought we were nuts,’ recalls Caroline. ‘Even my father didn’t think we should sell our house in London, saying, “You never know what you might be thinking this time next year.” But we’re both stubborn and we were convinced we were doing the right thing.’

Starting Pedlars as a mail-order catalogue, initially selling children’s clothes, was in response to the need ‘to do something creative but still have family as our focus’, says Caroline.

They became pioneers of the lifestyle catalogue, with idyllic images of themselves, their children and friends as models, though this was more from necessity than a marketing ploy.

‘The catalogue was the only way we could do it – we couldn’t have opened a shop because we were in the middle of nowhere, six miles from the nearest village, and with no phone signal,’ they say.

Surely their background has had its advantages?

‘Just because you’re privileged and you have a large inheritance doesn’t mean you have the one thing that makes life a lot easier, namely money…that we don’t have,’ says Charlie.

‘I’m not pretending that the family properties aren’t well endowed, but we’ve had to make our own running.’

Charlie thinks the key thing that comes from privilege is confidence, and ‘from that confidence comes creativity.

'Somehow it means we don’t seem to have any fear about creating new things, whether it’s six children or moving to the depths of Scotland, or starting a festival just because we want to.

'As long as we can keep our heads above water and have an interesting time, employing people, I’m happy.’

Charlie’s fearlessness presumably comes from the extraordinary spirit inherited from his liberal-minded, working-class-hero great-great-grandfather William Gladstone (or just Gladstone, as Charlie affectionately refers to him).

‘The older I get, the more interested in Gladstone I become. I wasn’t always so keen on all that family stuff, because I’m not an historian as such,’ he confesses.

‘But when you have an ancestor like that – and we’ve inherited the mantle of living in and looking after his house – it can’t help but rub off on you.’

As president of Gladstone’s library, Charlie has learnt just how significant his great-great-grandfather was: ‘Someone on the library’s trustee board told me the other day that Gladstone was unquestionably the most famous man in the world for most of the 19th century, and every working-class household in Britain had a memento of him.’

Gladstone served as prime minister four times and passed 12 budgets as chancellor of the exchequer; he resigned aged 84.

With such strong familial ties to one of the country’s most revered political figures, as well as maternal links to Cecil Beaton (his mother’s uncle) and growing up with his own inspirational father – Sir William Gladstone, a retired teacher and former Royal Navy officer, who was also Chief Scout from 1972 to 1982 – Charlie says he could do nothing but ‘have the confidence to believe I can do anything’.

This sense of heritage fires the Gladstones’ passion for provenance.

‘Whether it’s Pedlars, the pub or farm shop, our emphasis has always been on heritage and things well made.

'I can’t have anything in my life that doesn’t have some sort of value, whether it’s a pencil, jacket or mug,’ says Charlie.

It’s a mentality maybe better understood with the foodies’ fork-to-fork culture, ‘but with homewares it’s a harder sell.

'What interests us is talking to the people we’re buying from or researching the pieces we’ve found and then telling our customers about them. It’s about the pieces coming with a story of their own.’

The Gladstones’ Good Life Experience – an annual festival at Hawarden – is an extension of all they love.

The festival’s seed was sown in early 2014, via a chance meeting with Steve Abbott, an old music business mate of Charlie’s, who happens to be married to Cerys Matthews, former Catatonia front woman and BBC Radio 6 presenter.

They discovered a shared hankering for traditions and a relish for the simpler things in life and together decided to create a new kind of retreat into the lost art of ‘making’.

‘It’s going to appeal to someone not so bothered by the conventional notion of a festival such as Hay or Glastonbury,’ enthuses Charlie, ‘but who wants to commit to something that’s quite different.

'The festival is our way of bringing people with an interest in food, music, culture and creating things together.’

Alongside leather working and knot tying, blacksmithing and sausage making, at last year’s festival the slots for Hatchet & Bear’s sessions in spoon-making sold out within ten minutes of opening.

‘It was heartening to find people prepared to spend three hours fashioning a wooden spoon from a block of wood,’ says Charlie.

Last year, visitors spanned all walks and ages of life.

‘Festival-goers loved the fact that Cerys was wandering around, talking to people,’ says Tara, the Gladstones’ 22-year-old daughter (and heir apparent to the Pedlars business), who will be managing the artists behind the scenes.

‘But we’ll never have a backstage or VIP area,’ says Charlie. ‘If an artist isn’t comfortable being among the crowd, they’ll simply have to leave the site as soon as they’ve performed. The Good Life Experience is about people connecting with others.’

It’s also a chance for the family’s farm shop and pub to get involved with the catering.

‘The food is going to be very good,’ Charlie enthuses. Backstage, the family is very much involved, with Tara taking the lead in organising the guest artists, chefs and speakers.

‘It’s the most important job on the day,’ says Charlie, ‘because it’s about someone who knows how to get hold of an artist when it’s their time to go on stage without panicking even if they’ve suddenly disappeared.’

‘I quite like being bossy,’ says Tara, ‘so I think I’ll enjoy it.’

Charlie and Caroline’s enthusiasm for hard work hasn’t been lost on their children – Jack, 26, India, 24, Tara, 22, Xanthe, 20, Kinvara, 18, and Felix, 15.

‘Living in Scotland has had a profound influence on the way the children are now,’ says Caroline.

‘I’m so glad our parents moved there; I think I would have hated growing up in London,’ agrees Tara. Not for this clan the antics of being papped falling drunk out of Boujis.

‘I’d rather be in Scotland, going for long walks with the dogs, than heading to the pub,’ says Tara.

Not that they’re all homebodies, either – just before we meet, the eight of them were scattered between Scotland, Wales, Pompeii, Rome, Sri Lanka, Paris and London.

‘That was particularly extreme,’ says Caroline.

‘We never really discussed having a large family,’ says Charlie, ‘but we both really love the crazy chaos that comes with six children and six dogs.’

So the good life’s far from living the high life for this entrepreneurial brood – you’ll find no private jets and fleets of staff here (they didn’t even have a nanny when the children were young).

‘We fold everything we earn back into what we do, and we certainly have no ambitions to own a superyacht,’ says Caroline.

Can everyone enjoy an element of the Gladstones’ idea of a good life?

‘I’m a great believer in flow,’ enthuses Charlie. ‘It’s that great meditative technique where you’re immersed in what you’re doing and it’s what brings people real happiness.’

So it’s not so much about being fancy, but about everybody having a go.

‘When my life is good, everything is in balance,’ he says. ‘The greatest day we can spend is all of us and some friends mucking about, probably at our house in Burgundy, having a great big sports day where no one’s allowed to get upset about losing, followed by a huge dinner around the campfire, where everyone eats and drinks too much and makes a lot of mess, and the seven-year-olds go to bed at the same time as the 50-somethings.

'That’s what we genuinely love the most; that’s our good life,’ he beams.
